>From: Derek James <blue5432@...>

>Basically, though, if you're interested in using SVG
>as a graphical layout tool (and even though I'm an
>advocate of its use for dynamic graphical generation
>and cross-platform utility, it is by no means the best
>or only way to graphically represent data), then you
>don't want to be coding it by hand.

I'm not...

>The power of SVG comes from leveraging data stored in
>XML format.

Sure, but you could use it to visualize anything, whether it was in XML or 
not.

Speaking of which, I finally got my network visualization algorithm tuned 
properly, with the forces of attraction vs. repulsion balanced so as to 
create the appropriate shape.  I've uploaded a sample to the files section 
of the group so you guys can see it.  This is the 'simplified' one, with 
only 147 nodes and their relationships.  The full data set has 63k 
nodes...there's no way I'd ever be able to view that one!!!

>I'm happy to answer any questions as well.

Do you have a good SVG online reference that you use?  I like to be able to 
look up all the attributes of a tag so I know what kinds of things I can do 
with it.
